ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: As someone who is not a native speaker/did not grow up in China, I found this course very challenging. However, Zhou Laoshi was very patient and generous with his time in and out of class to review grammar/vocab. I definitely feel as though I've deepened my understanding of formal chinese.
How to write Chinese articles as a news reporter

We read news from a variety of topics like notable figures passing away, space exploration, military conflicts, conferences, government visits, etc. In class discussion we ended up learning about the topics themselves too.

Vocabulary and sentence structures related to certain topics of news stories, such as natural disasters, diplomatic events, military conflicts, coups, space exploration, etc. Emphasis formal-register speaking and writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: William Zhou is a very caring and understandable Professor! 
Weakness : Works aren't much but a bit more to be remembered and keep track of weekly and daily - bit confused when trying to predict my grade at the end for too many works to take into account

Really well-organized, it is always clear what homework we need to do by when. But not set in stone; professor Zhou is really considerate of students' workloads so when some students voiced out that there was too much homework, he took off some of the default assignments for certain weeks. It's a really engaging course with textual, video, image sources all in authentic formal Chinese mapped directly to informal Chinese equivalents. The professor gave us a bonus handout with common formal Chinese grammars and news phrases as well as stepped through the texts word by word during class which was super helpful for getting used to the way Chinese write news. I hardly needed to study for the exams with how much professor Zhou trained us to convert informal and formal Chinese in our brains.

Strengths: The different units were on very interesting topics. I liked the small class size of 8 students. The course is well-organized.
Areas for improvement: Perhaps more opportunities to speak in class could be added, though I am glad that we didn't have to do a formal presentation each week, that would be too much work. But something similar to the  assignments could create more low-pressure opportunities for practice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For students who want to write formally, this is definitely an enriching course to take!

Yes, this course was super fun. There was some variation of Chinese level among students, but you get out what you put in from the class, so more advanced students could still benefit from more practice with the formal register, since Yale's L1-L5 classes mostly focus on casual, colloquial speech and writing.
Yes, if they are interested in learning to speak more formally, or better understand official news reports/articles in Chinese.
